Far from great but not bad either, Homefront is a straightforward action thriller with some corny writing & gripping action.

Home Front" is a tense, adrenaline-fueled thriller that will keep you on the edge of your seat from start to finish.  
The film's strongest asset is its well-crafted storyline, which expertly balances action, suspense, and drama. The script, penned by Sylvester Stallone, is intelligent and engaging, with well-developed characters that add depth to the narrative.

Jason Statham delivers a solid performance as the rugged and principled Phil Broker, bringing a sense of gravitas and intensity to the role. James Franco, on the other hand, is chillingly effective as the unhinged Gator Bodine, bringing a level of unpredictability to the film's tense confrontations.

The action sequences are expertly choreographed and intense, with a notable showdown between Statham and Franco that will leave you breathless.

I had good reason to into this film with high expectations. The film has action movie legend, Jason Statham, along with great MMA action fighter, Frank Grillo. Combine that with Sylvester Stallone as a writer. Don't laugh. Stallone is an Oscar winning writer. He has written 5 of my favorite movies. Yes, all five of those were all for the same underdog boxer, regardless, with this combination, I had every reason to be excited for some good fun action. Sadly, what I got was a little too sloppy in execution to be considered fun.

What Stallone excels in as a writer is simplicity. Setting up characters we like, and having them overcome advisories we don't like. And when the movie is focused on this, it can be fun. When the characters are allowed to just be characters, there are some legitimately good moments.

The story let's these characters down. The instigating event of this movie is just stupid. The idea that all these problems happen because of this little thing, is just so dumb, the quicker the movie gets away from it, the better. There are action scenes that fell like they were written first, and then they hastily tried to get our characters involved in them. A character literally asks 3 different characters, "Why are you even here?" and we the audience are wondering the same thing.

Some usual action movie problems are present here as well. You have Statham and Grillo fight but cut the scene to death so no one can see what's going on. There are some explosions that would kill any one besides the main character, but their plot armor is to thick to present any danger. The movie also feels like it is incomplete, like it is setting up a sequel that is never going to happen.

Not a complete mess, but overall it is just sloppy.

I find it interesting how this has a rotten score and the consensus is "adds nothing new to the genre". I often find action films get a low critic's score unless they do something that makes them wholly unconventional. The problem with that bar is I do not seek unconventional when I'm in the mood for a decent action flic. I want great actors, a believable premise, a capable hero, a titillating bad guy, a good story, and a whole lot of kick ass. I prefer not to see a lot of circumvention of the genre if it takes away from these basic elements. This story was great, and if anything, the end might have been BETTER if it stuck to a more predictable convention. However, the ending allowed for some serious acting displays from the sympathetic bad guys James Franco and Winona Ryder, and I am here for it. If you want an old school action film with great acting, real stakes, and a lot of kick-ass, this is simply an ideal choice. Critics need to step aside if they are not action film connoisseurs. To please them may have required a less formulaic, and thus less cathartic action thriller.
